document.masterDocTitle: On Gerridae (Insecta: Heteroptera) from Bhutan, with description of a new species of Onychotrechus Kirkaldy, 1903

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: On Gerridae (Insecta: Heteroptera) from Bhutan, with description of a new species of Onychotrechus Kirkaldy, 1903

subSubSection.paragraph:
Material examined. Holotype (apterous male), " BHUTAN : Sarpang Prov.\ Geylephug – Shempang rd.\ 10km NNE Geylephug, 400m \
26 ° 56 ’ 43 ”N
90 ° 31 ’ 29 ”E
\
26.11 . 2005
, leg. M. Jäch ( 29 )", in the Natural History Museum Vienna.

Type locality.
Bhutan , Sarpang Province, along road between Geylephug and Shempang, ca. 10 km NNE Geylephug,
26 ° 56 ’ 43 ”N
90 ° 31 ’ 29 ”E
, alt. ca. 400 m a.s.l., creek with large rock boulders in forested area (
Fig. 3
).

Description of holotype .
Size: apterous male, length 3.72 , width 1.17 .

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 1–3.
Onychotrechus jaechi
sp.n.
(1) habitus of holotype (apterous male), dorsal view (see text for size); (2) same specimen, ventral view of body after dissection of abdominal segment 8 and genitalia; (3) small stream NNE of Geylephug, habitat of
Onychotrechus jaechi
sp.n.
(photo: M.A. Jäch).

FIGURES 4–11. Morphological structures of males of
Onychotrechus
spp. (4) fore leg of
O . jaechi
sp.n.
; (5) proctiger of
O. jaechi
sp.n.
, dorsal view; (6) same, of

; (7) left paramere of
O. jaechi
sp.n.
, lateral view; (8) same, ventral view; (9) same, of

, lateral view; (10) endosoma of

.

subSubSection.paragraph: Etymology. This species is named in honour of Dr. Manfred A. Jäch (Natural History Museum Vienna) who discovered this interesting species.

Remarks.
Onychotrechus jaechi
sp.n.
is closely related to
O . robustus
described from northwestern India (
Andersen 1980
) and recently also collected in Nepal (Assess-HKH, unpublished data). Males of both species have a basally incrassate fore femur (with distinct dark stripes; Figs. 1, 2 ,
4
), a patch of long hairs on the basal part of the flexor side of the fore tibia (
Fig. 4
), a mesosternal impression (
Fig. 5
), a short abdomen ( Figs. 1, 2 ), and a long hind coxa (
Fig. 1
). However, the male of the new species can be easily separated from
O . robustus
by the following characteristics: The fore tibia is strongly curved (
Fig. 4
; only basally curved in
O . robustus
). The middle femur has small, less erect spines (middle femur of
O . robustus
with long, erect spines set in a distinct row). The posterior swelling of the mesosternum bears long black setae (
Fig. 2
; absent in
O . robustus
). The median groove of the mesosternum has long, black setae (
Fig. 2
; short black pegs in
O . robustus
). The metasternum is oriented almost vertically (
Fig. 2
; horizontally in
O . robustus
). The proctiger is short and has an obtuse apex (long and slender, with more acute apex in
O . robustus
; comp.
Figs. 5 and 6
). The apex of the paramere is strongly curved mediad (flat and club-shaped in
O . robustus
; comp.
Figs. 7–9
). The dorsal sclerite of the endosoma is basally strongly curved (slanted in
O . robustus
; comp.
Figs. 10 and 11
). The female of
O . jaechi
sp.n.
is so far unknown. The pattern of black stripes is much more extended in
O . jaechi
sp.n.
(
Fig. 1
) than described for
O . robustus
by
Andersen ( 1980 )
, but we have seen new specimens of
O . robustus
from India which are relatively dark in colour and not much different from
O . jaechi
sp.n.
